properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall expected today into Wednesday. Total snowfall amounts of 20 to 40 cm are possible. Precipitation has started as rain and will change to snow this evening. Snowfall amounts of 10 to 20 cm are possible by Tuesday morning. Additional snowfall amounts of 10 to 20 cm are a possibility Tuesday through Wednesday morning, Strong northerly winds gusting near 70 km/h are also possible tonight and Tuesday, particularly near Lake Huron or Georgian Bay. This snowfall is a result of a strengthening low pressure system expected to move through eastern Ontario into Quebec Tuesday into Wednesday. Precipitation associated with this low pressure system is expected to move east of the area by Wednesday. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-01T13:50:14-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-30T21:51:14-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2413356847.2020
Area: Bruce Peninsula - Sauble Beach - Tobermory, Hanover - Dundalk - Southern Grey County, Shelburne - Mansfield - Northern Dufferin County, Orangeville - Grand Valley - Southern Dufferin County

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, and significant snow melt are expected. Total rainfall amount: 40 to 60 mm, possibly higher in areas of heaviest rain. Location: Northwest New Brunswick. Time span: this evening through Wednesday morning. Remarks: A slow moving, intense low pressure system will move into New England tonight and into southern Quebec on Wednesday. Rain ahead of this system will begin this evening and become heavy at times tonight. Total rainfall amounts of 40 to 60 mm are expected before rain gradually ends Wednesday morning. Mild temperatures accompanying the rain will cause significant or total melting of the existing snow pack. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-01T11:43:31-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-30T19:44:31-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1103087936.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Total snowfall amounts of 15 to 25 centimetres are possible starting Tuesday afternoon through Wednesday morning. The combination of this particularly heavy snow and moderate winds could cause broken tree limbs. There is a also a risk of freezing precipitation late Tuesday evening. Travel conditions could also be difficult. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Summary:
Description: Multi-day snowfall event expected tonight into Wednesday. Total snowfall amounts of 10 to 20 cm are possible. Precipitation has begun as rain or snow and will change to snow this evening. Snowfall amounts of 5 to 10 cm are possible by Tuesday morning. Additional snowfall amounts of 5 to 10 cm are a possibility Tuesday through Wednesday, Motorists should be prepared for winter driving conditions. This snowfall is a result of a strengthening low pressure system expected to move through eastern Ontario into Quebec Tuesday into Wednesday. Precipitation associated with this low pressure system is expected to move east of the area by Wednesday night. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Extended period of rain expected. Locations: eastern New Brunswick. Time span: late this evening through Wednesday afternoon. Potential Rainfall amount: possibly exceeding 50 mm. Remarks: A prolonged period of rain is expected across New Brunswick beginning later today and persisting into Wednesday. While the heaviest rain from this system is forecast to fall over western New Brunswick, over eastern sections total rainfall amounts could exceed 50 mm in some areas and rainfall warnings may yet be required. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall expected Tuesday into Wednesday. Snow, heavy at times, and blowing snow will begin early Tuesday morning and continue into Wednesday. Snowfall amounts of 20 to 30 centimetres are expected before the snow weakens Wednesday afternoon. Falling snow, along with wind gusts up to 70 km/h will allow for blowing snow to occur and significantly affect visibilities Tuesday and Tuesday night. This snowfall is the result of a strengthening low pressure system expected to move through eastern Ontario into Quebec Tuesday into Wednesday. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Messy week ahead with periods of snow, freezing rain, and rain expected. Total snowfall: 10 to 20 cm. Total rainfall: 10 to 40 mm. Freezing rain duration: 8 to 12 hours. Locations: central Labrador and coastal Labrador from Hopedale and vicinity to Cartwright. Time span: overnight tonight until Thursday afternoon. Remarks: Snow, over western Labrador, will spread to central and coastal Labrador by Tuesday morning. North of Rigolet, the precipitation is expected to remain as snow through Wednesday. From Rigolet to Cartwright and through Upper Lake Melville and Eagle River the snow will change to rain Tuesday afternoon or evening then to a potentially extended and significant period of freezing rain overnight Tuesday night through Wednesday. Eastern areas of Eagle River and coastal areas of Cartwright to Black Tickle may avoid the freezing rain as temperatures should remain just above freezing. All areas should see the precipitation transition to rain Wednesday night into Thursday. The heaviest snowfall rates are expected during the day on Tuesday and the heaviest freezing rainfall rates are expected overnight Tuesday and into Wednesday morning. This wintry mix of snow, freezing rain and rain is expected to finally end later on Thursday. Snowfall, Freezing Rain, and/or Rainfall Warnings might be needed for some areas in subsequent forecasts. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-12-01T11:28:29-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-30T19:29:29-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0975149543.2020

properties.Title: Storm Surge Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Warning of potential breaking sea conditions and overwash issued jointly by Fisheries and Oceans Canada (Science) and the Meteorological Service of Canada - Quebec Region on 2020-11-30. An intense low pressure system will generate strong southeasterly winds over the specified areas below. The combination of these winds and the current run of mid-amplitude tidal ranges may produce minor breaking sea conditions along the coast near the following localities on the dates and at the times specified (Eastern Standard Time). Forillon Park - Gaspé - Percé: 2020-12-01, from 12:00 PM to 04:00 PM. New-Carlisle - Chandler: 2020-12-01, from 12:30 PM to 04:30 PM. Anticosti: 2020-12-01, from 12:00 PM to 04:00 PM. Natashquan: 2020-12-01, from 10:00 AM to 02:00 PM. Chevery: 2020-12-01, from 09:30 AM to 01:30 PM. ### Coastal erosion is possible in vulnerable areas. Storm surge warnings are issued when water levels pose a threat to coastal regions. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-01T12:53:00-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-30T20:54:00-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1290712017.2020

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long episode of rain, at times heavy, is expected. The Gaspé Peninsula and the North Shore will see 70 to 100 millimetres of rain between Monday evening and Wednesday. properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. Locations: Labrador City, Wabush, Churchill Falls and vicinity, and Churchill Valley. Time span: tonight and Tuesday. Remarks: The heaviest snow is expected overnight tonight and Tuesday morning. The snow will change to rain Tuesday afternoon over the Churchill Valley region, then to a long and significant period of freezing rain Tuesday night through Wednesday. Further west through Churchill Falls, Labrador City, and Wabush, periods of snow are expected to continue through Tuesday night with an extended and potentially significant period of ice pellets and freezing rain likely on Wednesday. A freezing rain warning is in effect for the Churchill Valley region and might need to be expanded to other regions in subsequent forecasts. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long episode of heavy rain is expected. The Gaspé Peninsula and the North Shore will receive 50 to 80 millimetres of rain from Monday evening to Wednesday. Strong southeasterly winds will combine with the poor weather conditions and could cause breaking sea conditions in some locations. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Strong westerly winds, with gusts in the 90 to 100 km/h range, are expected today. The wind is forecast to weaken late this afternoon. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall Tuesday into Wednesday. Total snowfall amounts of 20 to 30 cm are possible. Precipitation will change to snow this evening with 5 to 15 cm possible. Snow is expected to become heavier Tuesday afternoon and overnight Tuesday. Strong north then shifting to northwesterly winds will create some lake enhancement off of Lake Huron. During this time 15 to 20 cm is possible. Strong northerly winds gusting near 70 km/h are also possible tonight and Tuesday, particularly near Lake Huron. This snowfall is a result of a strengthening low pressure system expected to move through eastern Ontario into Quebec Tuesday into Wednesday. Precipitation associated with this low pressure system is expected to move east of the area by Wednesday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Summary:
Description: A total of 15 to 20 centimetres of snow is expected by tomorrow morning. There is a risk of freezing rain overnight. Temperatures will then rise above the freezing mark Tuesday morning and precipitation will change to rain. Travel conditions could be difficult. ### Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain is expected or occurring. Locations: Trans-Labrador Highway from Happy Valley - Goose Bay to Churchill Falls. Time span: overnight Tuesday night until midday Wednesday. Freezing Rain Amounts: 10 to 15 mm. Remarks: Precipitation will begin as snow this evening and become heavy, at times, early Tuesday morning. The heavy snow will transition to rain Tuesday afternoon before changing to an extended period of freezing rain Tuesday night. Precipitation will change to rain during the day on Wednesday as temperatures rise above the freezing mark. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-12-01T11:29:29-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long episode of heavy rain is expected. Maximum rainfall amounts: 80 to 120 mm, except possibly reach 180 mm in the extreme southwestern region of the province. Locations: most of southwestern and central New Brunswick. Time span: this evening through Wednesday morning. Remarks: A slow moving, intense low pressure system will move into New England later today and into Quebec on Wednesday. This system will push rain at times heavy into the province beginning this evening and continuing Tuesday and Tuesday night before easing off Wednesday morning. At this time, rainfall amounts are expected to be heaviest in the southwestern portion of the province where general rainfall amounts of 80 to 120 mm are expected by Wednesday morning, with some areas potentially reaching near 180 mm. Similar rainfall events in the past have caused road washouts and localized flooding in low-lying areas. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-01T11:42:53-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-30T19:43:53-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1750620316.2020

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. Maximum rainfall amounts: widespread 50 to 80 mm, with some areas possibly exceeding 100 mm in areas of heaviest rain. Locations: western Nova Scotia. Time span: tonight through Wednesday morning. Remarks: An intense low pressure system will move into New England this evening. Rain ahead of this system will reach western Nova Scotia near midnight tonight and become heavy at times by Tuesday morning. Heavy rain will then continue until Wednesday morning when a slow moving cold front eventually passes over the area. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
